turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: No we haven't met, but they said I could tell; that you looked like a boxer.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: Yeah, it's true. You do look like a boxer. John Garfield, in Body and Soul. Exactly John Garfield anyone told you that Father?

turns.speaker: KARRAS
turns.text: Do people tell you look like Paul Newman?

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: You this director was doing a film here, Burke Dennings?

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: You've seen him. You're also familiar with how last week he died?

turns.speaker: KARRAS
turns.text: Only what I read in the papers.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: Papers. Tell me, what do you know about the subject of witchcraft? From the witching end, not the hunting.

turns.speaker: KARRAS
turns.text: I once did a paper on it

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: I know. I read it. These desecration's in the churchÂ…you think they have anything to do with witchcraft?

turns.speaker: KARRAS
turns.text: Maybe. Some rituals used in Black Mass. Maybe.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: And Dennings, you read how he died?

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: Let me tell you how Father, and please confidential. Burke Dennings, good Father, was found at the bottom of those steps leading to 'M' Street, with his head turned completely around. Facing backwards.

turns.speaker: KARRAS
turns.text: Couldn't it of happened on the fall.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: Exactly. So on the one hand we've got a witchcraft type of murder and a Black Mass style of desecration in the church.

turns.speaker: KARRAS
turns.text: You think the killer and the desecrator are the same?

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: Maybe somebody crazy, someone with a spite against the church, some unconscious rebellion, perhaps.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: Look, Father this is hard for you- please. But for priests on the campus here, you're the psychiatrist; you'd know who was sick at the time, who wasn't. I mean this kind of sickness. You'd know that.

turns.speaker: KARRAS
turns.text: I don't know anyone who fits the description.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: Ah, doctor's ethics. If you knew you wouldn't tell, huh?

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: Not to bother you with trivia, but a psychiatrist in sunny California was thrown in jail for not telling the judge what he knew about a patient.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: No, I mentioned it only in passing.

turns.speaker: KARRAS
turns.text: Incidentally I mention only in passing that I could tell the judge that it was a matter of confession.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: I get passes to the best shows in town. Mrs. K though, she gets tired and never likes to go.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: Yeah, I hate to go alone. You know, I like to talk film; discuss the critique. D'you wanna see a film with me? I got passes to The Crest. It's Othello.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: Who's in it? Debbie Reynolds, Desdemona, and Othello, Groucho Marx. You're happy?

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: One last time: Can you think of some priest who fits the bill?

turns.speaker: KARRAS
turns.text: Alright. You know who I think really did it?

turns.speaker: KARRAS
turns.text: The Dominicans. Go pick on them.

turns.speaker: KINDERMAN
turns.text: I could have you deported, you know that?

turns.speaker: REGAN/DEMON
turns.text: Stick your cock up her ass! You mother fucking, worthless cocksucker!

turns.speaker: REGAN/DEMON
turns.text: Your mother sucks cocks in hell Karras, you faithless slime!

turns.speaker: MERRIN
turns.text: Almighty Lord, word of God the father Jesus Christ, God and Lord of all creation, who gave to your holy apostle the power to tramp underfoot serpents and scorpions. Grant me, your unworthy servant pardon for all my sins...

turns.speaker: MERRIN
turns.text: I cast you out!!! Unclean spirit...!

turns.speaker: REGAN/DEMON
turns.text: Shove it up your ass you faggot!

turns.speaker: MERRIN
turns.text: ...in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ!!! It is he who commands you! He who flung you from the heights of Heaven to the depths of hell!

turns.speaker: REGAN/DEMON
turns.text: You killed your mother!!! You left her alone to die!!!! She'll never forgive you!!! Bastard!!!

turns.speaker: UNCLE
turns.text: We want to see Mrs. Karras.

turns.speaker: UNCLE
turns.text: Yes I am her brother, he's the son

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: If I ask him to tell me, will you let him answer?

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: If he talks to me, I think he'll leave you. Do you want him to leave you?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You wanted to see me, Charlie?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Now?  Why not tomorrow?  After the show.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I've got the grands for two nights, Charlie.  You can't just --

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Look, Frankie.  You and Jack been playing here, a long time.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Right, twelve years.  Couple times a month.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: So maybe it's time we took a vacation from each other.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Vacation?  Christ, Charlie, it's a Monday night. You said so yourself.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: It wasn't half full out there tonight, Frankie. I got six waiters standing in back listening to baseball.  I gotta move the liquor. To move the liquor, I gotta fill the tables. It's a matter of economics.  Me, I love you. I love both you guys, you know that. You're class.  But people today. They don't know class if it walks up and grabs 'em by the balls.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Too bad.  You could use some sun. Really.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Nothing's the matter. Is it, sweetheart?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: I'll take her inside.  You too, little Frank.  Out of the pool.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You believe this?  The kid won't come out.  I'm playing 'Camptown Races' for him and the next thing I know he's locked himself in the bathroom. There's nothing sharp in there, is there?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Where are our kids? Has he got one of them in there?

turns.speaker: DR. BEASLEY
turns.text: Uh-oh.  That's not good.  Let's get him up here.

turns.speaker: DR. BEASLEY
turns.text: Five's my guess.  Maybe more. Won't know till I get in there.  Leave him now and you can pick him up in the morning.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Isn't there something you can give him?  A pill or something?

turns.speaker: DR. BEASLEY
turns.text: Decay unfortunately doesn't limit itself to the denture, Mr. Baker. It spreads into his chest. Then the heart goes. We wouldn't want that, would we?

turns.speaker: DR. BEASLEY
turns.text: Start him out on cottage cheese. If you've got him on kibble, just soak it a few minutes.  Go down like pudding through a hot pipe.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What do you do to him?

turns.speaker: DR. BEASLEY
turns.text: Don't worry, Mr. Baker.  We'll knock him out. He won't feel a thing.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I think maybe I'll bring him back next week ...

turns.speaker: DR. BEASLEY
turns.text: The sooner we do this the better, Mr. Baker.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: My brother and I. One each.

turns.speaker: EARL
turns.text: Knee.  Tore it up against St. Anthony's.  Right before the accident.

turns.speaker: EARL
turns.text: The fire.  The way we're going we'll be lucky to buy a carton of jockstraps, let alone a new gym.

turns.speaker: EARL
turns.text: What do you say we go for a walk, pal.

turns.speaker: EARL
turns.text: Come on, friend.  I can smell it on you. Get yourself a cup of coffee.  You'll forget what you're angry about.

turns.speaker: EARL
turns.text: You're a real tough guy when the ladies are around, aren't you, Ace?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I don't see any ladies here. Except maybe you.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: Well, if it isn't the fabulous Baker Boys!

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: A little stiffer, but just as sturdy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Uh, Ma, you know, no one calls him that anymore. Jack. He goes by Jack.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: I thought maybe held gotten over that.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: Yes, yes.  It's just that John is so much nicer. Jack sounds so ... crude. When I was a little girl, we had a pig on the farm named Jack. I guess I just can't help making the association.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Uh ... yeah, well, you know, Ma, John Kennedy went by Jack.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: Catholics.  What do you expect? Oh, well, what's in a name, right? Let's go inside and have a look at that cake.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: I thought these were lost. Where did you find ...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: In the attic.  Behind some of Dad's stuff.  Look, Jack can hardly reach the pedals.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I had a boy down at the camera shop cut them all together.  Boy, old man Henderson didn't fool around when he gave a haircut, did he, Jack?

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: Oh, look at you two.  So skinny. And those tiny suits ...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What happened to the two Clays, Willie?

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Wednesday next. Frank looks across the room at Jack.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Tag 'em, Willie.  The Regency downtown, Thursday-Friday.  Thanks.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Great.  Terrific.  Glad you could make it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How we ... ? What, are you kidding me?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You cannot continue to walk in at the last moment, Jack.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You want me to show up late a few nights?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Frank.  I'm here.  I always get here.  Don't sweat it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Christ, will you look at your hair?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You look like you just crawled out of bed.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: No one's gonna be looking at my hair.  Come on, we're on.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You know, my brother and I have been playing together, gosh, I don't know.  How long has it been, Jack?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's a lot of water under the bridge, eh, Jack?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Of course, back then, things were a little different.  I was eight, Jack was seven, just about the only song we knew was 'My Bonnie Lies Over the Ocean', and the only one who would listen to us was the family cat, Cecil.  We must have shaved three lives off that cat, eh, Jack?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Who's gonna make trouble?  Hey, amigo!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You mind telling me what that was about in there? Was that planned? Or were you just bored and decided to get creative?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: This isn't the Pine Tree Inn on Route 81, Jack.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Fuck him.  Great.  Terrific.  Fuck him.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Maybe Thursday.  I hear the harpist at the Sheraton's got appendicitis.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Listen ... why don't you come out to the house this weekend.  Say hello to the kids. They've grown.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Only by relation.  Besides, they hate me, too.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They don't.  They're always asking about you.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: They tried to electrocute me, Frank.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It was no fucking accident, Frank. The little one ...

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: She threw a goddamn radio into the bathtub. How do you explain that?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She didn't know what she was doing. You're too sensitive.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Look, I just thought if you came out you might see what you're missing.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What d'you say, Willie?  Tighten her up?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You know, I think it's been five years since I saw you eat anything. That's the God's truth.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Trust me, you're not missing anything.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Because I'm your brother.  Because I care about you. Because sometimes it seems like the most significant relationship in your life is with that goddamn dog of yours.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm not seeing anyone.  In particular.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What about that waitress at the Ambassador?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Uh-uh.  How about you?  You seeing anyone?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It's only a ring.  Not a collar.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: By the way, we gotta go see Ma tomorrow.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: No, you gotta go 'cause if you don't get up there every couple weeks you feel guilty. I won't feel guilty, so I don't gotta go.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You're thirteen months older than me, Frank. That might've meant something in the Apache clubhouse, but it don't cut too deep anymore.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah.  Listen ... come out to the house tomorrow, will ya?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I've had enough family for one month, Frank.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: So talk to me tomorrow.  After the gig.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Something came up.  Don't worry, Charlie stayed true.  Both nights. I'll give you your share tomorrow. At the house.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Honey, it's only Uncle Jack.  You remember Uncle Jack.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah ... we're gonna paint in the spring. After the rains.  Look good as new.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You ask me out here to sell me your house, Frank?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Charlie paid you off last night, didn't he?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't know what you mean.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I told you.  Something came up. Some political dinner or something.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Bullshit.  Fifteen years, Frank. No one paid us off.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hey pal, I got a mortgage, all right? I got two kids. I got a wife. Besides, he made the deal. There's no shame in it.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: A gust of wind killed him.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, and what put him up there?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Look, can we forget last night? We gotta talk.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I been thinking maybe we should make some changes.  I been thinking maybe we should take on a singer.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's just an idea.  I want your opinion. I mean, we go halfway on everything, right?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It's more like 40-60, wouldn't you say?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We agreed that if I took care of the business; I'd be entitled to the extra. Isn't that what we agreed?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: If you're unhappy with the arrangement --

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: If you'd like to assume more of the financial responsibilities, I'd be glad --

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I've tried to do well by you, Jack. By both of us.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm grateful, Frank.  How much? For the singer.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I thought maybe twenty percent. Look, with the additional bookings we'll come out ahead.  The big hotels, they want a pretty girl with a big voice. We have to stay competitive, Jack.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You, Frank.  All these years you been telling me we're different.  We got novelty, Jack. No one can touch us.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Two pianos isn't enough anymore, Jack.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Thirty-seven girls. And not one who can carry a tune. That must be statistically impossible.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It was a somewhat extraordinary day.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I just don't understand.  You would think someone ... anyone ...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I just thought we should talk about it.  Between ourselves.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What's there to talk about?  She can sing. That puts her at the head of the class. That makes her the only one in the class.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't know ... She had gum on her lip, for Christ sake. I don't think she's right for the act.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You're getting cold feet about this.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I was just thinking what Ma would think.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Ma? Ma?  Was Ma there the last time we played the Ambassador?  Oh, that's right, she was on bass. How could I forget.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: How many other silent partners are there, Frank? Donna?  Little Cindy? Hell, let's give Eddie a vote.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay, okay.  I'll call the girl.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I suppose we can bring it down a little.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I told everyone seven-fifteen. Didn't I? Seven-fifteen.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Just like the day of the auditions, right?  Jesus.  How's my hair?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, well, Your's isn't.  Let me run a comb though it.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'll hit you, Frank.  I swear.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I told you I was gonna hit you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: All right, all right.  I'm a little tense.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I just wish she'd get here, that's all.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Jack, for crying out loud.  Your bachelorhood's showing.  Ah, here we go.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: And it's especially nice to be among friends tonight, because, well, tonight's a very special night for my brother and I. This evening we've asked a young lady to join us, a lady Jack and I are sure will soon seem like just another old friend to you all.  She's making her debut here this evening and, as far as I'm concerned, she couldn't be doing it in a better place. Because there's one place that's always been for us a very special place, and that place is this place, the Ambassador Lounge.  Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome a very special lady with a very special way of singing a song, Miss Susie Diamond.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Sounds like a booking agent looking to book an easy fee.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's what I figure.  Probably have us in a bed-and-breakfast playing to the owls.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's it except for the first. We got the Sheraton, the Ambassador, or the Holiday Inn on Sixtieth.  All three-day turns.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Better take care of your fingers, little brother. Buy yourself a case of arthritis and you won't be able to play 'Chopsticks.'

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay I'll see you tomorrow night then.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, well, what can I say?  Dad must've had forty pounds on me. Jesus, you remember him being this big?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well, the line's growing weaker, little brother. Lucky for us there aren't any dragons left to slay.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You want to come out to the house tomorrow? The way the bookings been piling up, Donna's decided to really lay it on.  Turkey, stuffing, the whole bit.  Kitchen's so full of food you can hardly move.  We could use another appetite.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: All right, but if you change your mind, let me know.  I gotta go get Ma in the morning anyway.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: When's the last time we played a wedding, Jack?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I thought we had separate rooms.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We do.  She's got hers, we've got ours. Hey. Wash and Dries.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I thought we all had separate rooms.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Come on, Jack.  It's not like it's the first time we've bunked together.  It'll be like when we were kids.  Relax.  Enjoy the view.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: She was staying at the Grand downtown ...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It was April.  April seventeenth. That one I remember.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: We were playing the lounge one night and she came in.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Frank asked if she'd sit in for a song, she said yes, and we did a few bars.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Not true.  Besides, Jack's the romantic.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm putting my stuff on the right, okay?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I figure that way we won't get confused.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We might as well do the towels the same way.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I just figure things'll go smoother, you know, if we have it all worked out from the beginning.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: But if it doesn't work out, let me know.  I'm,flexible.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: We're gonna be here a week?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: So you're gonna leave it on. Every night.  For a week.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't know.  I mean, I always did it as a kid. I figured it was no big deal.  Is it?  A big deal?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Accommodate?  I don't think I know what you mean.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I think what Mr. Daniels is trying to say, Jack, is --

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Why don't we let Mr. Daniels tell us what he's trying to say.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Jack ... Jack ... You're acting like a kid.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: No, that's your problem, Frank.  You get around one of these assholes and you turn into a fucking three-year-old.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What's the matter with you?  So the piano's a little out of tune.  So what?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No! I never hear it!  Maybe.  Sometimes.  I don't know. But I won't let it bother me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What matters to me is we've got the six easiest nights we've had in ten years. So 'Tie a Yellow Ribbon' sounds a little flat. So what?  Nobody's gonna hear it, Jack.  Nobody. So why should you care?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well, then stuff cotton in your ears, because come six o'clock we're gonna walk into that dining room with smiles on. Understand, little brother?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Thank you, thank you.  You know, Susie and Jack and I only just arrived here yesterday, but already the people here at the King Corporation's Moorish Manor have made us feel, well, a part of the family. And it's their hope that, before you leave, everyone of you will feel a part of that family also.  So, if during-the next few days, we should happen to pass one another in the hallway or in the lobby or wherever ... don't be a stranger. Stop.  Say hello.  Introduce yourself.  Because here, there are no strangers, only friends. And family.  Right, Jack?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I love you.  I just wanted to say it.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm sorry, Frank.  All that talk about family. I just got emotional.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How dare you say you love me.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It won't happen again.  Scout's honor.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What the hell are you doing?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What's it look like I'm doing? I'm tuning a goddamn piano.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yes, really.  I don't want you to be unhappy, Jack.  If you say it's out of tune, it's out of tune.
